title: Generate seccomp.bpf during build
body:
This is a proposal for a runtime independent handling of the `seccomp.bpf` file. This allows support for additional architectures like `aarch64` or `arm` (see #126).

#### How does it work?
* A specific `seccomp.bpf` is generated via `build.rs` during compilation.
  * The generated `seccomp.bpf` matches the `target_arch` of the `rua` binary. It's no longer required to distinguish different versions during runtime.
  * The `seccomp.bpf` is embedded to the binary, just like the prebuilt ones before. During runtime it is extracted to `.system/seccomp.bpf`. (The prebuilt files are removed by this pull request.)
* A new *build-time* dependency `libscmp` is introduced to generate the `seccomp.bpf` file.
  * There are various crates available for that purpose but to me `libscmp` seems most appealing. It has a very low footprint and provides all required features (especially `seccomp_syscall_resolve_name` and `seccomp_export_bpf`). An alternative would be the `libseccomp` crate.
 
#### How can it be tested / reviewed?
* The implementation exports next to the `seccomp.bpf` a `seccomp.pfc` to `OUT_DIR` containing the human-readable output of the filter. (This second file is not embedded to the binary but can easily be inspected.)
* The `md5sum` for the `seccomp.bpf` file generated by this implementation is identical to the old one generated by [seccomp](https://github.com/kurnevsky/dotfiles/blob/master/.seccomp/) (https://github.com/kurnevsky/dotfiles/commit/1432bf8ae2b62f16142b7c87ad2e0fd28d27e9fc).
```sh
$ find . -name \*.bpf -exec md5sum {} \;
de85db9cf299f131c51cecee5f84ce77  ./res/seccomp-i686.bpf
f9cd17bc2fe18abc4f672071dd9e0c9c  ./res/seccomp-x86_64.bpf
de85db9cf299f131c51cecee5f84ce77  ./target/i686-unknown-linux-gnu/debug/build/rua-5b88deb180f14f08/out/seccomp.bpf
f9cd17bc2fe18abc4f672071dd9e0c9c  ./target/x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/debug/build/rua-bdd5a199bf2717e3/out/seccomp.bpf
```

#### Remarks
* The `seccomp.bpf` file can contain the ruleset for all supported architecures at once. This comes with an increased file size but may reduce the logic in `build.rs` by a few lines. (I don't think it's worth it.)

I hope this helps. In case another solution fits better, I'm happy to revise.
